factoid: The troops were running in a dense mass.
Once surrounded by the troops, it was difficult to get out again.
One person shouted 'Get on! Why are you hindering us?'.
Another person turned round and fired in the air.
A third person struck the horse that Kutúzov rode.
Kutúzov got away to the left from the flood of men by great effort.
Kutúzov’s suite was diminished by more than half.
Kutúzov rode toward a nearby sound of artillery fire.
Prince Andrew forced his way out of the crowd of fugitives.
Prince Andrew tried to keep near Kutúzov.
Prince Andrew saw on the slope of the hill amid the smoke a Russian battery that was still firing.
Prince Andrew saw Frenchmen running toward the Russian battery.
Some Russian infantry stood higher up.
The Russian infantry neither moved forward to protect the battery nor moved backward with the fleeing crowd.
A mounted general separated himself from the infantry.
The mounted general approached Kutúzov.
Of Kutúzov’s suite only four remained.
The four were all pale.
The four exchanged looks in silence.
Kutúzov gasped 'Stop those wretches!' to the regimental commander.
Kutúzov pointed to the flying soldiers.
Bullets flew hissing across the regiment and across Kutúzov’s suite like a flock of little birds.
The French attacked the battery.
The French saw Kutúzov.
The French were firing at Kutúzov.
After the volley the regimental commander clutched at his leg.
Several soldiers fell.
A second lieutenant holding the flag let the flag fall from his hands.
The flag swayed and fell.
The flag caught on the muskets of the nearest soldiers.
The soldiers started firing without orders.
Kutúzov groaned 'Oh! Oh! Oh!' despairingly and looked around.
Kutúzov whispered 'Bolkónski!' his voice trembling from the consciousness of the feebleness of age.
Kutúzov whispered 'Bolkónski!' pointing to the disordered battalion and at the enemy, asking 'what’s that?'.
Prince Andrew felt tears of shame and anger choking him.
Prince Andrew leapt from his horse and ran to the standard.
Prince Andrew shouted 'Forward, lads!' in a voice piercing as a child’s.
Prince Andrew thought 'Here it is!' while seizing the staff of the standard.
Prince Andrew heard with pleasure the whistle of bullets evidently aimed at him.
Several soldiers fell.
Prince Andrew shouted 'Hurrah!'.
Prince Andrew was scarcely able to hold up the heavy standard.
Prince Andrew ran forward with full confidence that the whole battalion would follow him.
Prince Andrew only ran a few steps alone.
One soldier moved and then another.
The whole battalion ran forward shouting 'Hurrah!' and overtook Prince Andrew.
A sergeant of the battalion ran up and took the flag that was swaying from its weight in Prince Andrew’s hands.
The sergeant was immediately killed.
Prince Andrew again seized the standard.
Prince Andrew dragged the standard by the staff and ran on with the battalion.
In front Prince Andrew saw our artillerymen.
Some artillerymen were fighting.
Some artillerymen, having abandoned their guns, were running toward Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew also saw French infantry soldiers.
The French infantry soldiers were seizing the artillery horses.
The French infantry soldiers were turning the guns round.
Prince Andrew and the battalion were already within twenty paces of the cannon.
Prince Andrew heard the whistle of bullets above him unceasingly.
Soldiers to the right and left of Prince Andrew continually groaned and dropped.
Prince Andrew did not look at those soldiers.
Prince Andrew looked only at what was going on in front of him—at the battery.
Prince Andrew now saw clearly the figure of a red-haired gunner.
The red-haired gunner had his shako knocked awry.
The red-haired gunner was pulling one end of a mop.
A French soldier tugged at the other end of the mop.
Prince Andrew could distinctly see the distraught yet angry expression on the faces of the red-haired gunner and the French soldier.
The two men evidently did not realize what they were doing.
Prince Andrew thought 'What are they about?' as he gazed at them.
Prince Andrew wondered why the red-haired gunner did not run away as he was unarmed.
Prince Andrew wondered why the Frenchman did not stab the gunner.
Prince Andrew thought the Frenchman would not get away before remembering his bayonet and stabbing him.
Another French soldier, trailing his musket, ran up to the struggling men.
The fate of the red-haired gunner, who had triumphantly secured the mop and still did not realize what awaited him, was about to be decided.
Prince Andrew did not see how it ended.
It seemed to Prince Andrew as though one of the soldiers near him hit him on the head with the full swing of a bludgeon.
The hit hurt a little.
The worst part was that the pain distracted Prince Andrew and prevented him from seeing what he had been looking at.
